name: Freetrade
tweet: In 1965, Pepsi merged with snacks company Frito-Lay, the owner of Doritos and crisps brand Layâ€™s.  At one point, the firm also owned KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell before they were spun off in the 1990s to become what is now Yum! Brands.  6/7  https://t.co/GKhNobOldJ

name: Freetrade
tweet: Pepsi's newfound popularity was such that then-Vice President Richard Nixon took it with him to Moscow in 1959.  Here's former Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev and Nixon drinking Pepsi in Moscow, when it was one of the only US products allowed to be sold in the Soviet Union.  5/7  https://t.co/MUaGL6yhOj

name: Freetrade
tweet: Loft then merged with Pepsi in 1941 with former Cola-Cola executive Alfred Steele joining Pepsi-Cola as CEO in 1949.  Steele massively increased Pepsiâ€™s advertising and marketing spend. The result was an 11-fold increase in Pepsi revenue over the next decade.  4/7  https://t.co/T0Bng3DTmN

name: Freetrade
tweet: In 1931, Pepsi-Cola was acquired by Charles Guth, the president of Loft, one of the world's largest candy makers.  Guth allegedly tried to sell the business to Coca-Cola in 1933, but then developed a new Pepsi formula and brand and banned Coke products from Loft stores.  3/7  https://t.co/Ke0LniF7MJ

name: Freetrade
tweet: Just like Coke, Pepsi-Cola was created by a pharmacist in the American South during the second half of the 19th Century.  But Caleb Bradham's drink struggled when the First World War started and rationing was introduced, and he eventually declared bankruptcy in 1923.  2/7  https://t.co/5dPwC08qgb
